bibl.author: Hannah Whitman Heyde
bibl.title: Hannah Whitman Heyde to Walt Whitman, 18 April [1889]
bibl.orgName: The Charles E. Feinberg Collection of the Papers of Walt Whitman, 1839-1919, Library of Congress, Washington, DC.

body.p: I do hope my dearest brother you are feeling a good deal better to day & do want you to be so much. my greatest comfort is thinking about your being pretty well comfortable.
You never complain are always patient Walt dear & an example for us all.
You are more than kind to write me such a long letter when you are not strong. I am so sick (and I do feel so sorry) is all the rest in the letter. Every word good to know.

I think of you always my dear brother, as I always like to tell you indeed Walt & dont
think I could live with out thinking about you—I mean you are so good to me and it is so good to have you to think of.
Walt dear if I could only write something cheerful, if I only could do anything for you—could see you
Everyone I know asks after you Mrs Tyler always & all her children, & Mrs Griswold never fails
I do feel your sending me this money Walt—you have sent me so much before, of course I should not have so many things my cloak for instance I must tell you again Walt you are first first
I have been working around this morning getting dinner & so on wanted to write anyway a line or two.
I am going to think you are better yet to day, your letter was written two days ago, I thank you very much for writing. I had not heard you was sick my dear brother
It is right pretty to hear about those wild flowers.—

closer.salute: Walt dear I send love with all my heart

postscript.p: Love to Lou & George and Edy
